text: uh hi everyone akvini fantober here the
internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of the new touche
amore record lament this is the latest
full-length lp
from california post hardcore and
screamo outfit touche amore
four years after the release of the
utterly devastating stage four
the narrative along with the throttling
anthemic rock instrumentals on that lp
are a high water mark not just for the
band but for screamo music in general
and i went into lament excited for the
potential of touche besting themselves
once again
on a new project now from the push of
play on this thing
you can tell the band is back in full
force the vocal mix on the intro track
is
great and the bass and drums are
sounding especially crisp
and resonant i mean come heroin might be
one of the best
engineered touche songs of all time
front man jeremy balm's impassioned
poetry about a heroine or
a savior of sorts cuts pretty deep too
and this is just a taste of what the
band has in store on this one because
deeper into the record
they really begin to diversify their
sound and even soften in some respects
while trying to hold on to those
post-hardcore routes but this doesn't
always result in their best stuff
for one the shimmering and reverb rhythm
guitars over a few passages on the title
track
really lack presence they're kind of
faint and as a result they leave
jeremy's lead vocals feeling kind of
unsupported
then there's the overpowering steel
guitar
on the song broadcast which
is really doing too much and mixed way
too high in the climactic second half
not only that but i kind of really doubt
these
twangy resonant notes really complement
touche style
then to talk about an awkward fit we
have vocals from manchester orchestras
andy hull
on the back end of limelight i mean i'm
sure the two bands have crossover
audience so the collaboration makes
sense but
hearing andy soaring leads totally
smothered by
jeremy's roars during this final portion
of the song
just really does nothing for me and
seems almost antithetical to having a
guest on the song in the first place
however i do love the song's narrative
about love changing over time
over the course of a long-term
relationship all the devastation and
i guess familiarity and how that shifts
one's view
and the intensity of love and lust and
attraction
it's also worth noting the two other big
teasers to this record are easily two of
two cheomori's most hook
driven songs ever there's reminders
which has a huge
shouty group vocal on the chorus that is
easily one of the most
joyous and righteous things on one of
this band's lps
something i think a lot of those kids
who are into the
uh the pop punk that's a little emo
tinged they'll be into it
then i'll be your host is surprisingly
infectious despite being so
harrowing lyrically as far as other
highlights on this thing go we have the
track
fane the harmonized guitar leads on this
one the way they trade off with these
throttling drum passages topped with
these speedy descending chords
it's so dynamic it's so aggressive
lyrically i think this track is pretty
revealing for jeremy ii
in many critical and underground rock
circles he is often revered as
a wordsmith but instead on this track he
portrays himself as someone who is just
feigning profundity now doubting
yourself lacking
faith in yourself these things are often
themes in touches music and they are
especially intense here i also love how
the band
totally nailed the balance between
explosive and melodic unsavoring the
blast beat passages
on this one are especially good then
from here we move on to a somewhat
respectable last leg
i love the way deflector explores these
feelings of extreme inadequacy
to the point where one might feel
totally useless or self-sabotaging
however i probably enjoy the lyrics more
than i do
the bland guitar work and so-so chords
the
distant muttered spoken word on the
bridge feels kind of cliche at this
point for this style of music
and sort of kills the momentum of the
song too then the closer of forecast
begins as this
very bare basic piano ballad eventually
rocketing off into this
harmonious screamo meltdown and the
first portion of the song is really
trying to have this raw
amateurish flair to it that feels almost
like
something little jeffrey lewis-ish or
even
daniel johnston-ish but falling
monstrously short
on its final moments the guitars and
drums certainly sound climactic but the
startup is just
so rough plus lyrically i think the song
misses an opportunity to really
tie the album up thematically somehow
though
it certainly delivers on its title there
is a lot of
lamenting though for touche amore that's
not entirely
new all things considered i think lament
has a lot of highlights on it quite a
few great moments but is it touche
amore's best record
in my opinion no there's a little more
stylistic versatility
the instrumentals are a bit more dynamic
too and i suppose
things are more general topically
certainly some instrumental change-ups
that didn't quite work along with some
writing that
felt a little typical for the band at
this point still i'd say i'm feeling a
strong 6 to a light 7
on this one tran position have you given
this album a listen did you love it did
you hate it
what would you rate it you're the best
you're the best what should i review
next
hit the like if you like please
subscribe and please don't cry hit the
bell as well
over here next to my head it's another
video that you can check out hit that up
or the link to subscribe to the channel
anthony fantano touche amore lament
forever
